Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend on their way to the airport calls, thinking they left their passport at home, and asks if you can check and bring it to them right away.
Situation2: The passenger’s train leaves soon and the station is across town
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was pulling up to a red light, my next passenger already in the back seat, nervously checking the time. It was Sam, my oldest friend, his voice tight with panic. “I think I left my passport at home. Can you check and bring it to the airport? My flight’s in two hours—I’ll miss it otherwise.” I glanced at the rearview mirror; my passenger’s eyes darted between his watch and the traffic, his suitcase clutched tight. He’d told me his train left in less than thirty minutes, and the station was clear across town. As a friend, I wanted to drop everything and help Sam—he’d do the same for me. But as a taxi driver, I had a responsibility to get my passenger to the station on time. My heart pounded as I weighed the desperate plea of a friend against the trust of a stranger relying on me. Both needed me, right now, in different ways. I gripped the steering wheel, torn, the seconds ticking by as I tried to figure out what to do.
